category.term: 2361~Parks and Recreation (TV Show)~The Office (TV Show)~Saturday Night Live~Amy Poehler
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Since its debut in 2009, Parks and Recreation has emerged as one of the most critically acclaimed comedies on network television. The low-key comedy about entry-level bureaucrats in small-town Indiana has earned multiple Emmy nominations, including for best actress (Amy Poehler) and best comedy series. Co-creator and executive producer Mike Schur, who also wrote for Saturday Night Live and The Office, sat down with Postmedia News to reveal his tricks to making TV romance convincing, and why he'll never use the words "Democrat" or "Republican" on his show.

Q: How did you get into TV writing?

A: When I was in college, I knew a guy who worked for Saturday Night Live, and he encouraged me to write a submission. I was dubious about whether I could build a career in TV, but I gave myself a year to live in New York and write. If I didn't get a job, I would have gone to grad school and become a miserable academic, but I submitted to SNL and got a job there after about six months.

Q: What kind of advice do you have for aspiring TV writers?

A: There's really no advice that's any good. There's nothing to do but write - I wrote constantly. I would write episodes for shows I didn't even like, just to get the voices right. . . . It's about endlessly doing it. (As) Malcolm Gladwell said, you have to it for 10,000 hours to be any good. It's different now from when I was coming up in TV, though, in the sense that there's more of a democracy in the creation of ideas. You literally have people with zero dollars who can write something and film it and put it on the Internet, and those videos do become calling cards.

Q: Which shows influence Parks & Recreation?

A: Two that come to mind are The West Wing and Northern Exposure. I remember, as a kid, falling in love with Cicely, Alaska.

Q: Would you say Canadians are big fans of your show?

A: Canada has been very supportive, and we've talked a lot about why that is. My theory is that our show is about local government, and government has essentially become a curse word in America. I think Canadians have a different view of their government.

Q: With America in an election year and Leslie Knope (Poehler)'s character also running for city council, do you guys use real political news as inspiration?

A: We certainly do. We've done some topical episodes, but the political fray is so fraught right now that I've been wary about adding to that. We've never used the words "Democrat" or "Republican" on the show, and I don't think we ever will. It's so tense and so awful right now that the second you seem to raise issues in any sort of partisan way, people start screaming and it all gets lost in the noise.

Q: Having also worked on The Office during the Pam and Jim years, as well as marrying Andy and April so quickly, how do you write romantic relationships on TV and keep them fresh?

A: With romance, the key is to follow the dictates of the characters you've created. That's where Andy and April came from. We sat down in pre-production on Season 3, and were like, "OK, what's the reality of these two people?" They're young and uninhibited. Andy is essentially a golden retriever and wears his heart on his sleeve, and they would both be open to doing something crazy, like getting married after three weeks. It's always scary for a show to put people together, though. That's why Ross and Rachel took nine years, why Sam and Diane broke up so many times, and why the finale of Cheers was about Diane showing up again. TV relationships have to be built to last a long time and stay interesting. But with Andy and April, we just felt like, screw it, this feels right for the characters.

Q: Do you think the audience expected something different when Parks and Rec started and became impatient when it didn't turn out to be that?

A: A show has numerous hurdles and obstacles to get past to be a success, and I really can't complain. We got the cast we wanted and such, but I do think the one hurdle we did have was the correlations to The Office. Originally, Parks and Rec was said to be a spinoff, but then it wasn't, which confused people. We also shot it mockumentary-style, like The Office. Amy Poehler got compared to Steve Carell. People just love comparing things, it's human nature. We could've set the show in a remote village in Morocco with a 72-year-old doctor as the lead, and people still would've said, "That guy is too much like Michael Scott." It was always going to happen, and we knew it.

Q: You directed the video for The Decemberists' Calamity Song, and, being a huge fan of the band, as well, I have to ask: What's your favourite Decemberists song?

A: Oh man, that is a really good question. . . . Can I cheat and say three? Besides Calamity Song, since it will always have a special place in my heart, I love the song Red Right Ankle; it's incredibly beautiful. They have a song on their first EP called Angel, Won't You Call Me? which I also love. There's so many.

Parks and Recreation airs Thursdays at 8:30 p.m. ET/PT on NBC and Citytv.

link.Abstract: "We're feeling pretty confident," executive producer Russ Krasnoff told the audience, giving the show a "63 percent" chance of renewal because "the people at NBC love the show."
link.title: Community Has 63% Chance of Returning, Producer Says at Paleyfest Panel

link.Abstract: According to creator Dan Harmon, the show will return to its 8 p.m. ET slot on NBC's Thursday night comedy lineup beginning March 15.
link.title: Community Set to Return to NBC's Lineup March 15

link.Abstract: A week after NBC announced it was benching Community for 30 Rock's return, the show's stars have started speaking out about what the decision could mean for its future and the online support it's received.
link.title: Community Stars React To Show's "Benching"

link.Abstract: The actor/rapper took time out of his busy Childish Gambino touring schedule to appeal to the hearts, minds and campaign letter writers of the world to demand Community's safe return.
link.title: Donald Glover Shoots a PSA for Community

link.Abstract: In the newly released clip, the Community star meets a cactus, a pineapple and a porcupine, and explains what makes them extra sharp.
link.title: Watch Joel McHale Explain 'Prickly' on Sesame Street
